__data__.text: The 57th Medical unit, initially established as the 57th Malaria Control Unit in 1943, underwent several reorganizations and designations over the years. It started as an Army of the United States unit, activated in Louisiana, and was redesignated as the 57th Malaria Control Detachment in 1945 while in Brazil. Later, it was allotted to the Regular Army, redesignated as the 57th Medical Detachment, and activated in Texas in 1953. The unit was then reorganized and redesignated as the 57th Medical Platoon in 1960, then as the 57th Medical Detachment in 1961, and finally as the 57th Medical Company in 1992. The unit was inactivated in 2007. Its combat service includes participation in the American Campaign of World War II and the Vietnam Advisory, Defense, and Counteroffensive campaigns, including Phase II.

The 57th Medical Unit, throughout its history, has been involved in various campaigns, including the American Campaign of World War II and several phases of the Vietnam Advisory, Defense, and Counteroffensive campaigns. It also participated in the Grenada conflict and the Defense of Saudi Arabia and Liberation and Defense of Kuwait during the Gulf War. The unit's decorations include the Presidential Unit Citation (Army) for the Dong Xoai operation, two Meritorious Unit Commendations (Army) for Vietnam service in 1964-1965 and 1968, and a Valorous Unit Award for the Detachment, 57th Medical Company. However, the Valorous Unit Award is not authorized for the company as a whole. The unit's final decoration is to be officially determined.

The 57th Medical Unit has received several Meritorious Unit Commendations (Army) for its service in Vietnam during various periods from 1964 to 1973, as well as in Southwest Asia in 1990-1991, 2003, and Iraq in 2005-2006. Additionally, the unit was awarded the Vietnamese Cross of Gallantry with Palm for its early involvement in Vietnam. However, not all of these commendations are authorized for the company as a whole, such as the Valorous Unit Award and the Vietnamese Cross of Gallantry with Palm. The unit's final decoration is yet to be officially determined.

The 57th Medical Unit's initial establishment occurred in 1953 at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, as the 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance), a General Reserve Unit. It was attached to the 37th Medical Battalion (Separate) for administration and the Medical Field Service School for training and operational control. Captain John W Hammett, the first commander, organized and equipped the unit, which was 95% ready by the end of 1953. The unit's early history includes its activation by General Order Number 10 and its involvement in the Vietnam War, for which it received the Vietnamese Cross of Gallantry with Palm, Streamer embroidered VIETNAM 1964.

The 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance) was established in 1953 at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, with 95% readiness by the end of the year. Initially, it was equipped with H-13E aircraft and had 6 officers and 26 enlisted men. The unit's primary activity was participating in evacuation demonstrations for the Medical Field Service School. However, the unit faced maintenance issues with the aircraft, leading to the abandonment of the initial training program. The detachment was then attached to the 37th Medical Battalion (Separate) for administration and training, and a modified training program was started, allowing more time for aircraft maintenance.

In October 1953, the 57th Medical Detachment resumed training with adjustments to accommodate aircraft maintenance, finishing by the end of the year. On January 7, 1954, the 57th and 274th Medical Detachments were moved from the Medical Field Service School to Brooke Army Medical Center for quarters and rations. During June 28 - July 4, 1954, all aircraft from Brooke Army Medical Center, including those of the 57th and 274th, were dispatched to aid flood relief efforts along the Rio Grande River near Langtry, Texas, due to Hurricane Agnes. They operated from Laughlin Air Force Base for their search missions.

In February-March 1955, the 67th Medical Group, including the 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance), took part in Exercise Blue Bolt at Fort Hood, Texas, providing medical support to the 1st Armored Division and III Corps. They evacuated a total of 1153 patients, consisting of 128 actual casualties and 1025 simulated patients. Prior to this, in July 1954, the 57th Medical Detachment had assisted in flood relief efforts near the Rio Grande River, operating from Laughlin Air Force Base and evacuating 85 passengers from a cut-off Southern Pacific train.

During Exercise Blue Bolt in February-March 1955, the 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance) evacuated 128 actual casualties to the 603d Medical Company (Clearing) and completed seven pickups with an impressive average delivery time of 38 minutes. Additionally, they evacuated a total of 1025 simulated and actual patients. Following this, the 67th Medical Group was reorganized as the 67th Medical Service Battalion (ATFA Provisional) on July 10, 1955, along with the 32d Medical Depot (Army), 47th and 53d Field Hospitals, and the 82d Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance). During this time, the 603d Medical Company (Clearing) operated an Evacuation Hospital that handled a total of 1200 patients, both simulated and actual.

In July 1955, the 32d Medical Depot (Army), 47th and 53d Field Hospitals, and the 82d Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance) were reorganized as ATFA Provisional units, similar to the 67th Medical Service Battalion (ATFA Provisional). Dental Service Team KJ (Provisional #1), Team KJ (Provisional #2), and Medical Detachment (ATFA Provisional Team QA) were also activated and attached to the 67th Medical Service Battalion (ATFA). These units, along with the 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance), were set to participate in Exercise Sagebrush. To prepare for this exercise, an extensive training program was implemented in September, despite facing challenges in personnel, equipment, and limited training time. By mid-October, after rigorous field preparation and special ATFA testing by Brooke Army Medical Center, the units were deemed ready for their responsibilities, though some newly assigned personnel in the field hospitals lacked the required MOS training. Just before departing, the Group held the largest mounted review in Brooke Army Medical Center's history.

Before departing, the Group showcased a significant mounted review at Brooke Army Medical Center with around 250 vehicles. In late October, all units traveled overland to Louisiana without major accidents, gaining valuable experience in atomic warfare and mass casualty management. The 67th Medical Service Battalion oversaw attached medical units, while the 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance) logged 289 hours in evacuation, reconnaissance, and supply missions. The 82d Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance), attached to III Corps, executed 313 flying hours across 165 missions. The 32d Medical Depot (ATFA) supported the Ninth Army with supplies. Hospitals treated both real and simulated casualties throughout the exercise.

The 32d Medical Depot (ATFA) played a crucial role in supporting the Ninth Army during the maneuver by managing around 10 tons of medical supplies. At the exercise's end, most ATFA units returned to Fort Sam Houston, except for the 47th Field Hospital, which stayed at Fort Polk, Louisiana, to assist Engineer and Signal Corps units. A portion of the 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance) prepared for an expedition to Alaska in January 1956 for Exercise Moose Horn. The remaining period in December was dedicated to organizing, cleaning, and returning ATFA equipment following General Order 42, Brooke Army Medical Center, on December 13, 1955.

After August 1956, the 57th and 82d Medical Detachments received new H-19D aircraft, distinguishing themselves with different painted backgrounds for the red cross on their noses. In 1957, the 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance) was assigned to the Office of the Surgeon General, operational control under Brooke Army Medical Center, administration and training with the 67th Medical Group, and received rations and quarters at Brooks Air Force Base. In October, the 57th was notified and prepared for a permanent change of station move to Fort George G. Meade, Maryland. This summary retains the original text's information about the 57th Medical Detachment's equipment, assignments, and relocation.

In October 1957, the 57th Medical Detachment received a movement directive and order to relocate to Fort George G. Meade, Maryland, with an advance party leaving on the 5th and the main body arriving on the 20th, including their H-19D aircraft. Upon arrival, they were assigned to the Office of the Surgeon General, attached to the Second US Army and Fort Meade, and further attached to the 68th Medical Group. Their mission remained training, with a secondary mission of providing emergency medical helicopter evacuations. In February 1958, they responded to emergency evacuation requests during a major snowstorm, but didn't fly any missions until the 18th.

In February 1958, following a major snowstorm that disrupted regular transportation, the 57th Medical Detachment started receiving requests for emergency evacuations on the 17th. However, they didn't begin flying missions until the next day, when the Second Army took operational control of their pilots, crews, and aircraft. On the 18th, they performed three evacuation missions: transporting two pregnant women from separate farmhouses to the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, delivering 20 cases of five-in-one rations to Fort Detrick and evacuating a pregnant woman from Woodbine to Fort Detrick, and evacuating two patients from farmhouses near Chestertown to Chestertown Airfield. The total flight time for these missions was 2 hours and 15 minutes, 3 hours and 5 minutes, and 2 hours and 30 minutes, respectively.

On February 18, 1958, the 57th Medical Detachment performed emergency evacuations, transporting two patients from farmhouses near Chestertown to Chestertown Airfield (2 hours and 30 minutes). The next day, they evacuated a patient from Lewisdale to a hospital in Laytonsville (3 hours and 10 minutes), and another patient from Sugar Loaf Mountain to Fredrick (2 hours and 20 minutes). They also delivered fuel twice to a farmhouse near Savage (30 minutes and 45 minutes) and flew 4 photographers to Crystal Beach (3 hours and 30 minutes). On February 22, they evacuated a patient from Smith Island to Crisfield Airfield. These missions demonstrate the detachment's commitment to providing essential services during challenging weather conditions.

From February 18 to July 1958, the 57th Medical Detachment consistently provided essential services, even in challenging weather conditions. They conducted emergency evacuations, transporting patients to various hospitals and airfields, delivering fuel, and flying photographers to their destination. On February 22, they evacuated a patient from Smith Island to Crisfield Airfield. A few days later, they searched for and transported the bodies of two drowned boys in Chestertown. The detachment also assisted the 68th Medical Group with exercises, and supported the 338th Medical Group at Fort Meade. They were put on standby alert for medical evacuation during a snowstorm in March, but it was quickly cleared and no evacuation was needed. Additionally, they helped the Philadelphia Electric Company by flying over power lines to check for damage. These actions demonstrate the detachment's dedication to their duties and ability to adapt to various situations.

In July and August 1958, the 57th Medical Detachment conducted simulated medical evacuations and orientation flights for various groups, including reserve personnel and Reserve Officers' Training Corps cadets. They also provided lectures and orientation rides at Fort Lee, Virginia. In September, the detachment undertook an unusual mission, transporting a tub of live fish from Rock Hall, Maryland to Deep Creek Lake in western Maryland for the Maryland Fish and Game Commission. Despite efforts to keep the fish alive during the flight, only four out of forty striped bass survived. These activities further illustrate the detachment's commitment to their duties and their ability to handle diverse tasks.

In September, the 57th Medical Detachment transported live fish for the Maryland Fish and Game Commission, conducted a nighttime field exercise at Fort Meade, had a helicopter on standby for potential casualties at Fort A.P. Hill from October 7 to 25, resulting in only one minor evacuation, and made a proficiency flight to Fort Bragg with two helicopters in November. These activities demonstrate their versatility and readiness to handle various tasks and situations. Unfortunately, the fish transportation mission was not successful as only 4 out of 40 striped bass survived. The detachment's new heliport lighting system was tested and successfully used for accurate nighttime landings during the September field exercise.

In November, the detachment conducted a proficiency flight to Fort Bragg and compared notes with their counterparts there. In December, they carried out an evacuation mission for an injured Army Lieutenant Colonel and his family, as well as transported a Tuberculosis patient to Valley Forge General Hospital. The month of January was generally calm until the detachment commander received a call from the Second Army Aviation Section later that month. These missions further illustrate the unit's readiness and capability to handle various tasks and situations.

In January 1959, the detachment commander received an urgent call to go to Meadeville, Pennsylvania, where an ice jam on French Creek was threatening to flood the town again following a recent flood that caused significant damage. The unit was tasked with transporting a demolition team, photographers, and a public information officer to blast the ice. Three H-19s carrying six demolition experts, two photographers, three crew chiefs, six pilots, and one borrowed pilot took off from Fort Meade and arrived in Meadeville at 1400 hours. They were met by the Reserve Advisors who took charge of the ice blasting operations. This mission further highlights the unit's readiness and capability to respond to various emergencies.

In response to an urgent request, a detachment sent three H-19 helicopters to Meadeville, Pennsylvania in January 1959 to address an ice jam on French Creek that threatened to flood the town. Upon arrival, the team collaborated with Reserve Advisors, who oversaw the ice blasting operations. The H-19s were utilized for reconnaissance, transporting TNT to the demolition team, and carrying the team to inaccessible areas. The mission was completed by 9 February, and two helicopters returned to Fort Meade. However, one aircraft remained in Meadeville due to engine failure, while another was sent to Atlanta for major overhaul. The team finally left Meadeville on 11 February. This event demonstrates the unit's readiness and capability to handle various emergencies.

The detachment's remaining party stayed in Meadeville until 11 February due to poor weather conditions. One helicopter was left behind because of engine trouble, and two pilots took another aircraft to Atlanta for maintenance, making a stop at Fort Benning to meet with the 37th Medical Battalion. The detachment conducted several medical evacuations in April and May, transporting patients to Valley Forge General Hospital and Walter Reed Army Medical Center. In June, the detachment sent aircraft to Atlantic City for a temporary duty and to Atlanta for SCAMP. An emergency medical supply run to Carlisle Barracks, Pennsylvania was completed in July using one helicopter. These events highlight the unit's readiness and ability to manage various missions and emergencies.

In July, the detachment showcased its capabilities by conducting a demonstration at Fort Indiantown Gap for reserve troops and delivering medical supplies to Carlisle Barracks. In August, the unit continued its mission, providing transportation for an injured Army officer from Bradford to Fort Meade, assisting a Naval doctor with an emergency medical situation during a flight to Bethesda Naval Hospital, and evacuating a patient to Valley Forge General Hospital. These events further illustrate the detachment's readiness and proficiency in managing diverse missions and emergencies.

In August, the detachment continued its mission by transporting an injured Army officer, assisting a Naval doctor during an emergency medical situation, and evacuating a patient to Valley Forge General Hospital. In the following months, the unit's medical evacuations remained busy, with a total of 16 patients transported by the end of November. This includes a patient with an injured kidney evacuated from Chestertown, Maryland to Fort Meade. The detachment also initiated regular evacuation runs from Carlisle Barracks to Valley Forge General Hospital, transitioning to the HU-1 as they prepared for the first air ambulance detachment.

In August through November 1959, the detachment was busy with medical evacuations, transporting a total of 16 patients, including an injured kidney patient from Chestertown, Maryland to Fort Meade. In December, evacuations decreased, with only 3 patients transported. In January 1960, two crews went to Fort Worth, Texas to pick up HU-1As, but one experienced frost pump trouble in Charlotte, North Carolina. Another crew picked up a HU-1A from Fort Worth and returned to Fort Meade. Two more crews left for Fort Worth with HU-1As on January 26th. By the end of January, the detachment had 5 HU-1As and 4 H-19Ds. On February 17, 1960, the detachment performed an emergency evacuation from Bainbridge to Bethesda Naval Hospital.

From January to March 1960, the detachment continued with medical evacuations and transport, including an emergency evacuation to Bethesda Naval Hospital using three aircraft. Three pilots successfully soloed in the HU-1As, with one setting a record for the fastest return time to Fort Meade despite adverse weather conditions. In late February, the detachment prepared for a field problem, but it was canceled due to a mechanical failure in one of the HU-1As, causing $60,000 in damage. In March, the unit undertook a snow emergency rescue mission in Cambridge, Maryland, and later received a call to assist in searching for a downed Air Force plane in Elkins, West Virginia.

Following the cancellation of a field problem due to a mechanical failure, the detachment conducted a snow emergency rescue mission and searched for a downed Air Force plane. In April, they flew General Ridgway in the HU-1A, impressing him. The unit was then sent to assist with disaster relief in Chile, with most personnel and four HU-1As deployed. Upon return in June, the detachment was reorganized and redesignated as the 57th Medical Platoon. They participated in a simulated medevac exercise at Fort Story, Virginia, before being redesignated as the 57th Medical Detachment in March 1961. An Asian exercise was planned for December 1961, but the 82d Medical Detachment was deployed instead of the 57th in March 1962. The detachment's operations in Vietnam followed from 1962 to 1973.

After being redesignated as the 57th Medical Detachment, the unit was deployed to Vietnam in 1962, with personnel and aircraft arriving in Saigon and Nha Trang in April. The detachment's aircraft were processed and loaded in Mobile, Alabama before being shipped to Saigon. The unit became operational in Nha Trang in May, with aircraft stationed in Nha Trang and Qui Nhon. This marked the beginning of the detachment's advisory support operations in Vietnam, which lasted until 1973.

Upon arriving in South Vietnam, the 57th Medical Detachment couldn't become operational at Qui Nhon immediately due to a lack of fuel and differing operational concepts. It wasn't until June 12, 1962, that they became operational there. In Nha Trang, they faced issues like insufficient communication for their primary mission and a lack of allocated space for setting up the detachment. Despite some challenges, a 3-2 split of aircraft and supporting personnel was implemented by the end of July 1962, although communication problems persisted. The detachment managed to acquire real estate but still lacked proper facilities for maintaining their organic aircraft.

The 57th Medical Detachment faced challenges in establishing operational capabilities due to insufficient facilities for maintaining their organic aircraft, even after acquiring their own real estate. As of July 1962, all supplies were stored in tents or Conex containers, and maintenance was conducted in the open, which was hindered by inclement weather. Logistical support was inadequate, affecting the detachment's overall operational capability, particularly due to being split into two locations. Despite being authorized five aircraft, only four were assigned, with one undergoing extensive repairs. The detachment's ability to maintain 24-hour operational capability was questioned due to the lack of logistical support for aircraft.

The 57th Medical Detachment's operational capabilities were impacted by insufficient facilities for maintaining their aircraft, which included storing supplies in tents and conducting maintenance in the open. A particular challenge was the lack of logistical support, which affected the flyability of their aircraft. As of October 1962, the detachment had requested a permanent facility, but its status was uncertain. The detachment was completely non-operational from mid-November to mid-December due to the turn-in of certain aircraft parts. Specifically, four aircraft were flyable but would soon require repairs, with one needing an unknown amount of time for replacement due to crash damage, and the others having a limited number of flying hours before needing repairs on their tail rotor hub assemblies. The detachment's ability to maintain 24-hour operational capability was uncertain due to these logistical challenges.

The 57th Medical Detachment's operational capabilities were affected by logistical challenges, including the turn-in of certain aircraft parts to another unit, which resulted in only one flyable aircraft from mid-November to the end of the year. This aircraft was rotated between Nha Trang and Qui Nhon. As of December 31, 1962, the detachment was authorized five aircraft, had four assigned, and one was operational. The remaining three aircraft were being prepared for shipment to the continental United States. Additionally, the detachment's orderly room was moved to a bamboo hut, providing better working conditions, but the unit supply remained in tents, which did not offer adequate storage or security for equipment.

The 57th Medical Detachment's supply storage remained in tents, which lacked proper security and storage solutions for equipment, with no updates on a hangar or additional workspace. The detachment's mission was to conduct aeromedical evacuations, but there was confusion about the priority of evacuees until the release of a regulation on September 4, 1963, which established the order as: US military and civilians, Vietnamese military personnel, and others for humanitarian reasons.

The regulation introduced a standardized procedure for requesting aeromedical evacuation and set the priority for evacuees. As a result, the 57th Medical Detachment was put in charge of evacuations in II, III, and IV Corps Tactical Zones, while the US Marine Corps handled evacuations in I Corps Tactical Zone. The detachment's organization and strength were updated according to Table of Organization and Equipment 8-500C with Change 2, allowing for an increase in officers from 7 to 10 due to the need for two aviators per aircraft in the Republic of Vietnam.

The Army Support Group, Vietnam authorized an increase in the 57th Medical Detachment's officers from 7 to 10 to accommodate two aviators per aircraft for flights in the Republic of Vietnam. The detachment's operational support was based from three locations in the country, with the headquarters section at Tan Son Nhut Airbase in Saigon for III and IV Corps Tactical Zones, and two separate sections in the II Corps Tactical Zone due to its large geographic area and rugged mountains, located in Qui Nhon and Pleiku. A request had been submitted to modify the unit's Table of Organization and Equipment.

To better support the large, mountainous II Corps Tactical Zone, the 57th Medical Detachment established two bases there. In March 1963, the unit replaced its UH-1As with UH-1Bs and experienced increased Viet Cong activity in the IV Corps Tactical Zone, requiring aircraft relocation. The detachment, still assigned to the 8th Field Hospital and under U.S. Army Support Group, Vietnam's control, operated below Table of Organization and Equipment (TOE) strength until April, when an Infantry officer joined the Qui Nhon crew. In June, three more officers from Combat arms were assigned, raising the officer count to ten, following the Commanding General's Verbal Orders of the U.S. Army Support Command, Vietnam.

In 1963, the 57th Medical Detachment's officer count increased to ten, with one Infantry officer, one Armor officer, and one Warrant Officer aviator joining the unit (the latter of whom was later replaced by another Armor officer). The enlisted strength remained near the authorized 23. Extensive training operations were not a priority, as the deployment was seen as a continuous exercise, and non-essential flights were minimized. Training focused on pilot and crew preparation and certification. Maintenance support ensured more than 68% aircraft availability despite the high workload of 2,094 flying hours for the year. (210 words -> 118 words)

In 1963, the 57th Medical Detachment's officer count rose to ten, and the enlisted strength remained near the authorized 23. Despite operating from three locations, the detachment maintained high aircraft availability due to extensive coordination with field maintenance units and a focus on pilot and crew preparation. Maintenance support was primarily handled by the detachment itself, with a heavy workload falling on the single-ship sections. Aeromedical evacuation requests were directed to the detachment through both Army and Air Force communications systems, while requests for coverage on airmobile assault operations were forwarded directly to the detachment commander for coordination.

In 1963, the 57th Medical Detachment provided coverage for every significant operation in the Republic of Vietnam, typically by stationing one aircraft at the assault staging area for immediate response. Night medical evacuation became a regular and specialized service for the detachment, which was equipped with an aircraft and crew ready for night operations at all three locations. The detachment accepted all legitimate evacuation requests, making it effectively available for aeromedical evacuations 24/7. Major evacuation for American casualties was usually carried out in the Saigon area, with patients being taken directly to the Tan Son Nhut airfield when possible.

In 1963, the 57th Medical Detachment was responsible for providing medical evacuation coverage during assault operations in the Republic of Vietnam, typically by stationing an aircraft at the staging area for immediate response. They offered 24/7 aeromedical evacuation services, accepting all legitimate requests. Casualties in the Saigon area, both American and Vietnamese, were usually taken to the Tan Son Nhut airfield. Initial medical aid was often given by the Medical Corps officer accompanying the assaulting unit. Vietnamese casualties were typically transported to the nearest field hospital, with further evacuation to the rear approved if requested by Vietnamese medical personnel and not against USASCV Regulation 59–1. The detachment's main duty was in-flight and emergency medical treatment, often being the first care received by the casualty. Additionally, they provided limited first aid to patients in staging areas. While medical evacuation was their primary task, the detachment also undertook various other missions, including providing coverage for armed and troop transport helicopters during combat heliborne assaults.

The 57th Medical Detachment offered aeromedical evacuation support for various missions, such as combat heliborne assaults, defoliation missions, training jumps, and transport of medical personnel and supplies. A significant challenge they faced was providing comprehensive medical evacuation coverage to all individuals, including American and Vietnamese combatants and non-combatants in South Vietnam. Although the Vietnamese were responsible for evacuating their own casualties, circumstances like high casualty numbers, insufficient aircraft, or extensive areas often hindered them. To address this issue, the detachment was divided into three operational sections, enhancing area coverage but reducing coverage in Saigon and southern regions. This adjustment was considered the lesser of two operational drawbacks.

The 57th Medical Detachment faced a challenge in providing complete medical evacuation coverage in South Vietnam due to the Vietnamese's limited resources. The detachment was divided into three sections to expand coverage, but this reduced coverage in Saigon and southern regions. Additionally, other aviation companies had to provide tactical aircraft for medical evacuations when the 57th's helicopters were unavailable, causing operational strain. The unit also struggled to prove its worth based on flying hours rather than the number of patients evacuated or lives saved. A study was underway to add another helicopter ambulance unit, which would alleviate some of these issues.

The 57th Medical Detachment determined their value was being measured solely by flight hours, not the number of patients evacuated or lives saved, which didn't accurately reflect their impact. This was because their yearly flight time relied on evacuation requests, without any additional administrative or logistical missions. Moreover, the detachment's flight time was less than other units due to their three-section setup for expanded coverage. Another study was initiated to explore integrating the 57th with other logistical units for increased effectiveness. Additionally, maintenance faced challenges due to the detachment's operation from three separate sections.

The 57th Medical Detachment's effectiveness was hindered by their operation from three separate sections, leading to increased maintenance man hours, reliance on neighboring units for aircraft, and communication challenges. The detachment suggested deploying a second air ambulance detachment and concentrating their aircraft at one location. During their first year, they lacked a tactical call sign and used "Army" along with the aircraft's serial number for identification, communicating on any available frequency.

The 57th Medical Detachment's functioning was impaired by using a makeshift communication system, which involved utilizing "Army" and the aircraft's serial number as identification and any vacant frequency for communication. Recognizing the need for a more formal system, Major Lloyd Spencer introduced the call sign "Dust Off" after visiting the Navy Support Activity, Saigon. This name, symbolizing medical evacuation missions in dusty conditions, became the enduring identity for Army aeromedical evacuation in Vietnam.

In January 1964, the 57th Medical Detachment, located at Tan Son Nhut airport, Saigon, established a permanent call sign "Dust Off" for its medical evacuation operations, instead of periodically rotating it for security reasons. This decision aimed to provide more efficient support to U.S. Forces in the Republic of Vietnam and assistance to the Republic of Vietnam, with two air ambulances and crews attached to the 52d Aviation Battalion in Pleiku and Qui Nhon, and the remaining three air ambulances and personnel with the 45th Transportation Battalion at Tan Son Nhut, all operating within the II, III, and IV Corps areas.

In January 1964, the 57th Medical Detachment established the permanent call sign "Dust Off" for its medical evacuation operations, initially supporting U.S. Forces and providing assistance to the Republic of Vietnam. The unit was first attached to the 145th Aviation Battalion, but later in January, it was moved to Headquarters Detachment, U.S. Army Support Group, Vietnam, and personnel relocated to the Support Group Compound. In February, due to increased activity in the lower Mekong Delta, Detachment A, 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance), (Provisional), was created and stationed at Soc Trang Airfield, attached to the Delta Aviation Battalion. This reorganization and relocation placed two aircraft with crews in Soc Trang and the remaining aircraft and personnel at Tan Son Nhut. The increase in patient evacuations during March confirmed the benefits of this strategic change.

The relocation of the 57th Medical Detachment in February 1964 led to a significant increase in patient evacuations, reaching a peak of 768 patients in July. This growth in evacuations also resulted in more flight time, missions, and regrettably, aircraft hit by enemy fire. In April, First Lieutenant Brian Conway was the first Medical Service Corp Aviator wounded in action in Vietnam. During spring and early summer, night flying time and missions also increased, with nighttime patient evacuations becoming routine, accomplished with a single helicopter flying in blackout conditions. Despite often encountering searching fire, the detachment only received one hit at night the entire year, highlighting their successful night operations.

The 57th Medical Detachment's night operations were successful, with only one aircraft hit despite frequently encountering enemy fire at night, mainly due to good U.S. Air Force radar coverage. In contrast, the South Vietnamese military did not have an aeromedical evacuation unit, and their VNAF responses to medical evacuation requests were inconsistent and dependent on various factors, often leading to mission aborts due to a lack of experienced decision-makers.

The MACV summary indicates that during the 57th Medical Detachment's night operations, the U.S. Air Force's radar coverage proved effective in minimizing damage, whereas the South Vietnamese military's medical evacuation efforts were inconsistent and often resulted in mission aborts due to insufficient decision-makers. A specific instance of subpar VNAF medical evacuation occurred during Operation LONG HUU II in late October 1963, where the ARVN 2d Battalion, 14th Regiment, was ambushed, leaving many soldiers wounded and dead. The battalion commander requested medical evacuation helicopters, but the response was delayed, and the number of casualties continued to rise.

The 57th Medical Detachment's night operations summary reveals that during Operation LONG HUU II, the ARVN 2d Battalion, 14th Regiment, experienced a significant delay in medical evacuation after being ambushed, resulting in rising casualties. The battalion commander made multiple requests for evacuation helicopters, and the American adviser designated two landing zones for the wounded. However, the VNAF H-34s only arrived at 1215, several hours after the initial request. Due to the extended wait, the ARVN battalion remained stationary to safeguard their casualties instead of pursuing the enemy. Furthermore, the ARVN medical services were insufficient to manage the high volume of casualties, causing backlogs at the main treatment center in the Delta.

The text discusses the challenges faced by the 57th Medical Detachment during Operation LONG HUU II in the Delta. The main treatment center, the Vietnamese Provincial Hospital at Can Tho, frequently had a backlog of patients, particularly at night when only one doctor was on duty due to insufficient ARVN medical physicians. Dustoff pilots had to make multiple flights to transport casualties, often finding injured soldiers still on the landing pad from previous flights. The ARVN officers' cultural beliefs regarding proper burial of the dead sometimes led to prioritizing flying out dead bodies over treating the living. This resulted in delays in evacuating wounded soldiers, as seen when a Dustoff crew noticed many ARVN wounded waiting while a dead body was being transported.

During Operation LONG HUU II, the 57th Medical Detachment faced challenges in evacuating wounded soldiers due to the ARVN officers' cultural beliefs, which sometimes prioritized flying out dead bodies first. This was demonstrated when a Dustoff crew, after landing near Saigon, noticed many ARVN wounded, but soldiers brought bodies to the helicopter for evacuation first. The Dustoff crew initially tried to prioritize the wounded, but when an ARVN soldier pointed a machine gun at their helicopter, they decided to fly out the bodies. The 57th Medical Detachment's resources were stretched thin with the increased demand for aeromedical evacuation, and they relied on a new group of inexperienced pilots and crews, except for Kelly, a dedicated soldier who was determined to complete tasks despite obstacles.

In Operation LONG HUU II, the 57th Medical Detachment encountered difficulties in evacuating wounded soldiers due to ARVN officers' cultural priorities. During this time, Kelly, a dedicated and determined soldier, emerged as a role model for Dustoff pilots. After the unit relocated to Soc Trang in March 1964, Kelly quickly adapted to the new environment, and his example of courage and dedication significantly contributed to the rise in Vietnamese evacuees from 193 in February to 416 in March.

In Operation LONG HUU II, the 57th Medical Detachment, under the leadership of Major Kelly, faced challenges in evacuating wounded soldiers due to cultural barriers. After moving to Soc Trang in March 1964, Kelly adapted to the new environment and became a role model for the pilots, leading to an increase in Vietnamese evacuees. In October 1964, Detachment A, including Kelly, transferred control to the 82nd Medical Detachment, and moved south to continue providing coverage in the Delta. Despite the contrast in living conditions between Soc Trang and Saigon, most pilots preferred Soc Trang. The Dustoff tradition of courageous and dedicated service was established under Kelly's command, with the help of two years of growing American involvement in Vietnam, which had 16,000 military personnel in South Vietnam by the spring of 1964.

By the spring of 1964, the US had deployed 16,000 military personnel, including 10,100 Army members, in South Vietnam, with a significant increase in Army aircraft. The 57th Medical Detachment, under Major Kelly, had been busy with a high volume of Dustoff requests. Upon Kelly's arrival, the detachment's helicopters were aging and overused, with an average flight time of 800 hours. However, the pilots flew over 100 hours a month for medical evacuations, sometimes exceeding the monthly ceiling of 140 hours. The team intensified night operations, flying 110 hours in April 1964 while evacuating 99 patients. Despite the lack of new aircraft, the pilots remained dedicated to their mission.

In April 1964, the 57th Medical Detachment under Major Kelly flew 110 hours at night, evacuating 99 patients. To enhance their night missions, the pilots conducted reconnaissance flights to map potential landing zones, identify terrain features, and check for radio navigation aid. During one such flight, they learned of a VNAF T-28 crash and joined the search, eventually finding the plane with Viet Cong forces shooting at them. Undeterred, Kelly landed the helicopter near the downed aircraft, and he and his crew secured the area, helped the pilot destroy his radios and remove machine guns, and safely returned the pilot to his unit.

In April 1964, Major Kelly and the 57th Medical Detachment undertook extensive night missions, often mapping potential landing zones and searching for downed pilots despite enemy fire. This is demonstrated by an incident where they found a VNAF T-28 pilot under attack by Viet Cong forces, secured the area, helped the pilot destroy his radios and remove machine guns, and safely returned him to his unit. Later, another Detachment A crew flew to Saigon from Soc Trang and responded to a call about a village overrun by the Viet Cong, where they evacuated the dead and wounded. Additionally, pilots Capt. Patrick Henry Brady and 2d Lt. Ernest J. Sylvester were on duty one night when they received a call about a downed A1-E Skyraider near Rach Gia and, with the guidance of an Air Force radar controller, flew to the landing zone while being cautious of Viet Cong antiaircraft guns.

In April 1964, Major Kelly and the 57th Medical Detachment conducted numerous night missions, including searching for downed pilots and evacuating the wounded amidst enemy fire. For instance, pilots Capt. Patrick Henry Brady and 2d Lt. Ernest J. Sylvester flew to a landing zone near Rach Gia to rescue a downed A1-E Skyraider pilot, despite Viet Cong antiaircraft guns. Although they faced enemy fire and their aircraft was hit, they managed to regain control and leave the area. A third aircraft eventually suppressed the enemy fire, enabling the evacuation of the downed pilot. Subsequently, Brady joined an ARVN combat assault mission near Phan Thiet, northeast of Saigon.

In April 1964, Major Kelly and the 57th Medical Detachment, including Captain Patrick Henry Brady, undertook various night missions, such as searching for downed pilots and evacuating the wounded amidst enemy fire. During a mission near Rach Gia, Brady and 2d Lt. Ernest J. Sylvester successfully rescued a Skyraider pilot despite facing enemy fire. Later, while supporting an ARVN combat assault mission near Phan Thiet, Brady's Dustoff ship had to avoid enemy ground fire while transporting wounded soldiers. After dropping off the wounded, Brady agreed to deliver ammunition to the ARVN unit under the guise of "preventive medicine" since his aircraft bore red crosses. Upon returning, Brady discovered that an L-19 observation plane had been shot down, and he retrieved the bodies of the American pilot and observer, loading them onto his helicopter.

In the mission near Rach Gia, Brady and Sylvester rescued a Skyraider pilot, and later, Brady transported wounded soldiers amidst enemy fire near Phan Thiet. Afterward, Brady retrieved the bodies of an American pilot and observer from a crashed L-19 observation plane, facing criticism from Major Kelly for carrying ammunition. However, Kelly commended Brady for bringing back the dead, which wasn't part of their mission statement. When questioned, Brady referred to the ammunition as "preventive medicine" and the dead as "angels" he couldn't refuse. The 57th Medical Detachment, including Kelly, were waiting for Brady upon his return to Tan Son Nhut.

In the subsequent mission, Brady explained his actions of carrying ammunition and retrieving the dead as "preventive medicine" and his duty towards the "angels." Major Kelly, understanding the potential repercussions, endorsed Brady's actions and expressed his desire for the 57th Medical Detachment to undertake such missions. As a result, the 57th became more proactive in seeking missions, with Kelly leading by example, flying almost every night. This was a strategic response to the increasing pressure from Support Command to place removable red crosses on the aircraft and accept general purpose missions, as the 57th needed to prove its indispensable role in medical evacuations.

In the subsequent mission, Major Kelly took the lead in flying almost every night, with his crew, to various locations in the region. They would depart from Soc Trang and head southwest to Bac Lieu, then further south to Ca Mau, and then reverse their course towards the Seven Canals area. After checking for casualties, they would proceed to Rach Gia, the Seven Mountains region on the Cambodian border, Can Tho, Vinh Long, Truc Giang, Phu Vinh, and finally return to Soc Trang. This was part of a strategic response to prove the 57th's indispensable role in medical evacuations amidst increasing pressure to accept general purpose missions.

Major Kelly and his crew frequently flew at night, covering 720 kilometers and stopping at multiple locations, to conduct medical evacuations. This "scarfing" strategy, which often involved transporting 10-15 patients per night, demonstrated the 57th's crucial role in evacuations and persuaded General Stilwell to abandon his plan of using removable red crosses. Despite most missions taking place over flat, marshy terrain, they also operated in the mountainous regions near the Cambodian border, such as Phnom Kto Mountain in An Giang Province.

On April 11, Major Kelly received a request to evacuate two wounded ARVN soldiers from a dangerous landing zone on Phnom Kto Mountain, part of the Seven Mountains in An Giang Province. Despite challenging conditions, including updrafts, mist, and darkness, as well as enemy fire, Kelly successfully landed his aircraft on a steep slope and waited for the soldiers to bring the second casualty. After loading both patients, Kelly flew through enemy fire again, ensuring their survival. This account illustrates Kelly's determination to complete missions, regardless of adverse weather, darkness, or enemy opposition.

Demonstrating great determination, Major Kelly undertook a mission to evacuate two wounded ARVN soldiers despite adverse weather, darkness, and enemy fire. Despite being forced away from the landing zone initially, he persisted and successfully loaded the patients, even as the enemy fired at his aircraft, causing fuel to leak. Disregarding his own safety, Kelly prioritized the patients' well-being and flew them to Soc Trang, where he received priority landing clearance. This account further highlights Kelly's unwavering commitment to completing missions, even in the face of significant challenges and risks.

Major Kelly, displaying determination, evacuated two wounded soldiers despite harsh conditions and enemy fire, prioritizing their well-being by ensuring priority landing and requesting ice cream upon arrival at Soc Trang. With a shortage of pilots for the 57th, Kelly successfully assigned following Medical Service Corps pilots to his unit, despite the Aviation Branch's plans to allocate them to non-medical units for combat training. In June 1964, Kelly formally addressed this issue. The text illustrates Kelly's dedication to the 57th's mission and his efforts to secure adequate resources.

Kelly emphasized the 57th's critical role in providing extensive combat-support flying experience, exceeding that of other units. He stressed the importance of keeping Medical Service Corps pilots in the 57th, which is a medical unit focused on casualty evacuation, as opposed to assigning them to non-medical units for combat training. Kelly highlighted the unit's impressive record of evacuating 1800 casualties and flying 242.7 hours at night, unescorted and with limited resources. He asserted that the 57th's experience is more valuable and stated his opposition to having combat arms officers in the unit, expressing that he would not raise this issue again. This summary conveys Kelly's strong commitment to the 57th's mission and his efforts to ensure the unit receives the necessary resources and personnel.

Kelly strongly believes that the 57th's mission of medical evacuation is crucial and requires specialized training with Medical Service Corps (MSC) pilots. He is against having combat arms officers in the unit and wants it to be fully staffed with MSC pilots. He acknowledges the increasing demand for evacuations and the limitations of other units in providing medical evacuation, emphasizing the unique and vital role of the 57th. He is committed to the unit's mission and requests full support for it, while also understanding the high workload of his superiors and not expecting a response. His letter conveys a strong sense of urgency and importance regarding the 57th's mission and the necessity of maintaining its focus on medical evacuation.

Kelly emphasizes the critical need for the 57th's medical evacuation mission, highlighting the lack of sufficient MSC pilots and resources for Army aviation in Vietnam. He acknowledges the high demand for evacuations and the constraints on other units. Despite these challenges, Kelly understands the limited resources available and recognizes the need to make do with what is available. He also realizes the potential impact of his presence at Tan Son Nhut, prompting him to consider returning there to better advocate for the 57th's mission.

Following Brady's repeated requests, Kelly agrees to transfer Detachment A command to him in Saigon, but later extends his stay in the Delta. The evacuation workload decreases from July, with August and September showing slight fluctuations before continuing to decline for the rest of the year. McGowan from the 82nd joining the 57th.

In October, there was a significant personnel exchange between the 57th and 82nd detachments, with six officers and four enlisted personnel moving to the other unit. Sylvester, and Lieutenant Bruce C. Zenk. That month, the 57th was also attached to the 145th Aviation Battalion, which led to an upgrade in living conditions for all personnel. In 1965, the 57th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance) was tasked with offering medical air ambulance services, which involved aeromedically evacuating patients, providing in-flight treatment and/or surveillance, and moving medical personnel and materials in support of military operations in specified zones of III, IV, and II Corps Tactical Zones. In 1968, the 57th Medical Detachment operated with 14 authorized aviators, although only 11-12 were available throughout the year. The term "stand-down" describes the process of closing down operations during redeployment.

The "stand-down" phase refers to the preparations for ending operations, while "withdrawal" refers to the actual redeployment of personnel. As a settlement in Vietnam approached, Cords Aviation was contracted to replace the DUSTOFF units in Military Regions III and IV. The 57th Medical Detachment's operations section was in charge of coordinating the transition, and each DUSTOFF unit had to communicate with their supported units and Cords' representative. A 50% readiness level was set for X+30, considering the anticipated withdrawal and deactivation.

The 57th Medical Detachment's operations section was responsible for overseeing the coordination of the transition, considering the anticipated withdrawal and deactivation. A 50% readiness level was determined to be appropriate for X+30, gradually achieved to ensure complete and professional execution of the detachment's mission. The detachment's mission requirements would end on X+45, followed by the termination of field standby in two stages. Notably, Operation Homecoming, the release of POWs, was a significant concern, with all personnel placed on 24-hour alert and given comprehensive briefings as the treaty took effect.

As the treaty for Operation Homecoming took effect, the 57th Medical Detachment's leadership put all personnel on high alert and briefed them thoroughly. Recognizing the need for additional resources, they arranged for aircraft and crews from the 247th Medical Detachment (Helicopter Ambulance) to reinforce the detachment. Collaboration with the U.S. Army Hospital in Saigon was established to facilitate the reporting and handover of returnees. In January 1973, an agreement was finalized with Cords Aviation, and DUSTOFF Operations Officers connected with their Air Operations Offices in each Military Region to ensure a seamless transition. In accordance with the plan, the detachment's field standby sites were shut down, and cavalry troops in their area ceased operations on the specified date, leading to the termination of the detachment's daily standby.

On the designated day (X-Day) for the cessation of cavalry operations in the 57th Medical Detachment's area, the detachment's daily standby ended as planned. A month later (X+30), the permanent standby in Can Tho also ceased, and the transition to Cords Aviation was completed without issues. The reduction of troops allowed for a 50% stand-down, which was slightly delayed but turned out to be suitable as the detachment's mission significantly decreased during the deactivation period. On X+45, the entire operation was terminated, and Cords Aviation took over the mission without any problems. The 57th Medical Detachment's role in Operation Homecoming lessened when two aircraft from Nha Trang reinforced their assets in Saigon and two ships were deployed to Can Tho. On X-Day, the detachment was on high alert with six ships and complete crews for their area of operations.

In preparation for POWs' release, two ships were sent to Can Tho and six ships with full crews were placed on alert in the 57th Medical Detachment's area on X-Day. The unit maintained this heightened readiness until X+10, when they received reliable intelligence about the release. Additionally, an extra ship and crew were required to be on standby for Vice President Agnew's visit to Saigon, resulting in one crew staying on the flight line for four days without breaks.

After being on standby for Vice President Agnew's visit, a crew remained on the flight line for four days without breaks. Once the special standby was completed, the unit resumed its regular alert rotation, with one ship in Can Tho and two in Saigon. When the first POW release was announced, the detachment was informed of its role and that only one Dustoff aircraft with a three-man crew would be needed. Despite objections, the small crew was assigned, received briefings, and prepared for the operation.

On February 9, 1973, a crew was selected and received detailed briefings for the POW release mission. The mission commenced on February 12, transporting one POW requiring urgent medical attention to Loc Ninh before returning to Tan Son Nhut Air Base. The second release, initially set for February 27, was postponed to March 4 due to issues with the major parties, and it occurred entirely from Hanoi. This marked the end of the detachment's role in POW releases. Prior to the hostilities' end, a tentative X plus date DEROS roster was created, considering mission requirements and projected strength levels, as ordered by higher headquarters.

After the POW release mission, a tentative roster was created to plan the drawdown of personnel in coordination with section leaders. The roster initially considered mission requirements and projected strength levels to reduce the unit's size gradually, starting with hard DEROS personnel and releasing others as their usefulness decreased. The goal was to have 22 personnel by X+30, who would stay until X+45 to fulfill mission needs. The remaining personnel would then depart as the unit inactivated. However, actual events deviated from the plan due to an unexpected surge of personnel and early closures of redeploying/inactivating units. Key personnel stayed until approximately X+51 to complete the detachment's final closeout.

After the mission to release POWs, the original plan to gradually reduce the unit's size was changed due to an unexpected influx of personnel and early closures of redeploying/inactivating units. The detachment adjusted its rotation schedule, reaching a fifty percent posture by X+34 and keeping 22 personnel until X+45 as initially planned. Once the POW issue was resolved on X+35, the detachment released personnel in groups until only four remained by X+49 to complete the final closeout. These four personnel then reported to Camp Alpha for their return to the United States on X+51, as outlined in Operation Countdown (OPLAN 215).

In the roll-up phase, as outlined in Operation Countdown (OPLAN 215), most unit property was transferred to ARVN or RVNAF before the peace treaty took effect, with the physical transfer occurring later. Any remaining property was to be turned in at the keystone facility in Long Binh Post. The detachment's aircraft were directed by the 1st Aviation Brigade G-4 section to be transferred to RVNAF, with three being handed over by X+30 and the remaining three by X+45. In practice, according to Operation Thunderbolt's guidelines, equipment was transferred to ARVN and RVNAF forces before X-Day and recorded as such until they were no longer needed.

In line with Operation Thunderbolt's guidelines, the detachment handed over equipment to ARVN and RVNAF forces before X-Day, keeping a hand receipt until it was no longer required. As per the 1st Aviation Brigade G-4's instructions, the 57th's aircraft were kept by the detachment for the RVNAF to sign for, with direct handling between the detachment, the Brigade, and the RVNAF. The first aircraft transfer occurred on February 16, 1973 (X+19), while the remaining aircraft were held until X+45, matching mission requirements. Delays in POW release affected the physical transfer of some aircraft, but were resolved by X+40, allowing for their transfer.
In line with the mission requirements, the remaining aircraft were kept until X+45 and transferred on X+49. Weapons, ammunition, and signal grenades were turned in by March 1, 197

Following the mission requirements, all property was transferred by the specified dates X+46 and X+49, with a final audit on X+50. The Military Aid to Safety and Traffic (MAST) program, established by Congress on July 1, 1974, enabled Army air ambulance units to offer aeromedical evacuation support to communities without competing civilian services. The 57th Medical Detachment at Fort Bragg, responsible for patient evacuation, emergency transportation of medical personnel and supplies, and uninterrupted delivery of essential medical items, began MAST operations soon after its establishment.

The 57th Medical Detachment at Fort Bragg, as part of the MAST program established by Congress in 1974, was responsible for providing aeromedical evacuation support, including the transportation of patients to and from Womack Army Hospital and civilian hospitals within a 100-kilometer radius. They experienced changes to their MTOE in 1975, which affected their ability to efficiently move supplies. Between July 1974 and April 1982, the detachment completed over 1000 MAST missions, with a significant portion of flight hours dedicated to these missions. In October 1980, they marked their 1000th MAST mission. In April 1982, the detachment was reorganized from a Regular Army (RA) Team to a Reserve Component (RC) Team. The mission's primary objective remained ensuring uninterrupted delivery of essential medical items, such as blood and biologicals, during critical requirements.

After being reorganized as a Reserve Component (RC) Team in April 1982, the 57th Medical Detachment replaced their UH-1 Aircraft with UH-60 Blackhawks, becoming the first non-divisional medical evacuation unit to receive advanced aircraft since the 1950s. They received the first operational UH-60 ambulance on 15 January 1982. The detachment achieved maintenance excellence and was recognized as a runner-up in the U.S. Army Forces Command Commanding General's Award in February 1983 and 1985. They also participated in Exercise Bright Star in Egypt in June 1983, demonstrating their capabilities with the new UH-60 Blackhawks.

The 57th Medical Detachment, having become a Reserve Component (RC) Team in 1982 and excelling in maintenance, was recognized with the Army Forces Command Commanding General's Award for Maintenance Excellence in 1983 and 1985. They accomplished over 1,500 MAST missions in Virginia, North Carolina, and South Carolina from 1974 to 1985. The detachment also assisted Joint Task Force Bravo in Honduras in 1988 and 1990, and provided support during Operation JUST CAUSE in Panama and Operation Green Stalk in Santa Fe, New Mexico in 1989 and 1991 respectively, although they did not receive campaign participation credit for the former.

After excelling in maintenance and receiving awards, the 57th Medical Detachment took part in various operations, including Operation Green Stalk, a counter-narcotics operation. Prior to their reorganization in September 16, 1992, they received equipment from the 36th Medical Detachment and provided relief efforts for Hurricane Andrew. Upon reorganization, they became the 57th Medical Company (Air Ambulance) with a new structure of 15 ships, consisting of three forward support MEDEVAC teams and a six-ship area support team, allowing for separate operation capability, unlike the previous structures.

After reorganizing in September 1992, the 57th Medical Company (Air Ambulance) adopted a new structure with 15 ships, enabling separate operation capability for each team through their own maintenance and refueling capabilities. This was an improvement from the previous structures of the 25-ship company and 6-ship detachment. The 57th Medical Company was a pioneer in reorganizing under this new structure. In early 1993, they supported a deployment in Honduras and in 1998, they undertook external missions providing MEDEVAC coverage to remote areas, including Fort Stewart, Georgia, and Fort Bragg, North Carolina.

Following its reorganization, the 57th Medical Company (Air Ambulance) began operating with 15 ships, allowing each team to function independently through their own maintenance and refueling. They provided MEDEVAC support in various locations such as Honduras, Fort Stewart, and Fort Bragg, and even maintained two UH-60As with aircrews in Saudi Arabia for Operation Southern Watch. In 1998, they supported Operation Purple Dragon at Fort Bragg and conducted a C-5 loadout with a Forward Support MEDEVAC Team for strategic air deployment training. The company also redeployed a team from Saudi Arabia using a C-17, taking advantage of the opportunity to develop load plans for the new aircraft. The unit's personnel had just returned from a 14-month deployment when the FORSCOM ARMS arrived at Fort Bragg.

After its reorganization, the 57th Medical Company (Air Ambulance) excelled in their operations, earning two of three FORSCOM Commander's coins for outstanding performance. They received commendable ratings and regained respect among the aviation units at Simmons Army Airfield. Following a 14-month deployment, the company underwent a change of command, with MAJ Harold Abner handing over to MAJ Scott Putzier. They then began preparing for their first External Evaluation (EXEVAL) in over 5 years. During this time, they conducted a train-up FTX, supported multiple battalions, and successfully executed a defensive live fire and a C-5 static load at Pope Air Force Base.

Following the change of command from MAJ Harold Abner to MAJ Scott Putzier, the 57th Medical Company (Air Ambulance) continued to excel in their operations. In September, they successfully carried out a defensive live fire on OP-9 and a C-5 static load at Pope Air Force Base. Following the leadership change, the 57th Medical Company (Air Ambulance) remained busy with various tasks, including a live fire exercise, a cargo load assessment, and supporting multiple units with aeromedical needs. After the leadership transition, the 57th Medical Company (Air Ambulance) stayed active with different tasks, including a live fire exercise, a cargo load assessment, and attending to medical evacuation needs of multiple units. The 57th Medical Company continued its support during the Global War on Terror and eventually cashed its colors.

After the 57th Medical Company's involvement in various operations, including hurricane relief and supporting the 82nd Airborne Division, it underwent an inactivation ceremony on 26th January 2007, marking the end of the unit. Most of its equipment and personnel were transferred to Company C, 2d Battalion, 82d Aviation Regiment, with the exception of the unit's lineage and honors, which remained inactive. This transition was part of a reengineering of Army aviation. The 57th Medical Detachment's role in the Global War on Terror and its eventual inactivation were marked by the casing of its colors.

Following its inactivation in 2007, the 57th Medical Detachment's records remain archived, including annual evacuation reports from 1958 to 1963. Notably, in 1962, the detachment transported 31 US and ARVN patients, along with medical supplies, while flying 890 hours and evacuating 235 patients. The peak activity occurred in September 1963, with 387 patients evacuated in that month and a daily high of 197 patients on the 10th of that month. The unit's lineage and honors are preserved despite its inactive status, marking its historical contributions.

After 2007, the 57th Medical Detachment's records have been archived, highlighting its significant role in evacuating patients. In 1963, the detachment reached its peak activity, evacuating 387 patients in September and having a daily high of 197 patients on the 10th. In the following years (1964-1972), the detachment continued to compile annual evacuation summaries, detailing total patient evacuations, number of missions, and aircraft hours flown for each year. This illustrates the unit's sustained and substantial involvement in patient evacuations throughout the Republic of Vietnam during this period.

The 57th Medical Detachment kept evacuation records for 1971 and 1972, showing their ongoing commitment to patient evacuations in the Republic of Vietnam. In 1972, they evacuated 77,940 patients in total from the start of their operations in May 1962 until the end of 1972. In 1975, the detachment conducted 839.2 flight hours and evacuated 669 patients, maintaining their crucial role in medical evacuations during that year.
